results.title: Aborigines in the Alice
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Looks at two problems facing First Nations people in Alice Springs - child care and alcoholism. In 1970 the death rate among First Nations children rose to nearly 1 in 5, one of the highest infant mortality rates in the world. Today the ratio has improved, but the health of First Nations people still presents a grim picture. Interviews people concerned. Reporter: Brian King; Photographer: Richard Bailie-Mace; Sound: Peter Lipscomb.

results.title: Aboriginal Education
results.creator_credit: John Sullivan, Ross Campbell and AVEC Film
results.brief_description: A survey of the progress made in education of First Nations people in Victoria in 1976. Shows the wide variety of educational courses operating and encourages communities in different areas to set up their own courses. Also presents the teaching of First Nations culture in primary schools and reasons people get involved.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Sullivan, Ross Campbell and AVEC Film
results.description: A survey of the progress made in education of First Nations people in Victoria in 1976. results.title: Aboriginal canoe trees of the Murray
results.creator_credit: Robert Edwards, South Australian Museum and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: First Nations people of the lower Murray River formerly made large canoes from the bark of Red Gum trees. This film documents the felling of a canoe tree from the sides of the Murray and its transportation to the South Australian Museum for preservation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Edwards, South Australian Museum and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.description: First Nations people of the lower Murray River formerly made large canoes from the bark of Red Gum trees. This film documents the felling of a canoe tree from the sides of the Murray and its transportation to the South Australian Museum for preservation.

results.title: Dad's tools
results.creator_credit: Fred Atwell, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: There is a lot to do after a bushfire but Fred Atwell wants more than anything to find his dad’s cherished homemade tools. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with Latrobe City and Arts Victoria.

results.title: Close to Slavery: Black Work in White History
results.brief_description: It was government policy for First Nations peoples in Australia to assimilate to the white ethics of education and work. Then came the mission stations, removal of children, forced labour often in the most deplorable conditions, exploitation and even when First Nations Australians were trained in skilled work through the mission stations, white Australians would not employ them - all this most comprehensively portrayed by the archival footage in this film.
results.title_for_label: Close to Slavery: Black Work in White History
results.description: It was government policy for First Nations peoples in Australia to assimilate to the white ethics of education and work. Then came the mission stations, removal of children, forced labour often in the most deplorable conditions, exploitation and even when First Nations Australians were trained in skilled work through the mission stations, white Australians would not employ them - all this most comprehensively portrayed by the archival footage in this film.

Then came the mission stations, removal of children, forced labour often in the most deplorable conditions, exploitation and even when First Nations Australians were trained in skilled work through the mission stations, white Australians would not employ them - all this most comprehensively portrayed by the archival footage in this film.

results.title: Paper War
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, ACMI and Guan Wei
results.brief_description: This simple tracking shot along Guan Wei’s exquisitely drawn battle scenes, silhouetted against a traditional landscape scroll, suggests the right-to-left movement of Chinese reading.
